description: This course is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation.
name: PRINCIPLES OF ACCOUNTING

values.comments:
ACCT 101 is an introduction to the basic concepts and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Several important concepts will be studied in detail, including: revenue recognition, inventory, long-lived assets, present value, and long term liabilities. The course emphasizes the construction of the basic financial accounting statements - the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement - as well as their interpretation. 

Students found the course content to be “dry” but “quite applicable to the real world.” A number of students were concerned that they “barely completed half of the course topics for the semester.” 

Professor Reis was, overall, “great.” Students described him as “approachable” and “extremely engaging,” but some did think that he “moved kind of slow” with respect to pacing the lectures which set the class back. 

A few students complained about the multiple choice format and the content of exams. They felt that the exam questions were very tricky, and it became “a game of guessing which questions [were] trick questions.” They also mentioned a disconnect between the assigned problems and the lectures. The grading adhered to a distribution, and most students took this to fulfill the Wharton Core requirement during their sophomore year.
